div1.p: We agreed at the close of the glorious meeting in Saint Louis that we would write longer letters and more frequently than we had and here I have been run ning about the land for nearly two months and I sent you not one word.

Well, here goes. We stopped for a day with the son of Lucy who has a department of ggricultureagriculture job at the University of Missouri,and saw him and his two children.His wife,a delightful little woman when she is herself is in a sanitarium,and will probably be there for the reoainderremainder of her life. A classmate of mine who was ,until recently, President of Doane College, preaches a sermon on "The Quiet Ways Of God".Is the situation above recorded one of them, a quiet way of destroying happiness for a family?
Our train stopped twenty minutes at Topeka and there we saw Darley L. House,son of my oldest brother who died recently.The son is a fine upstanding chap,and we both love him.

Nothing more except travel till we came to Los Angeles,where Mary Mrs. Morrie Rysbard met us and took us to Beverly Hills.Of course we met a lot of notables,whodowho do not interest me particularly,but they were a jolly crowd. Mary's children w are stunning youngsters. Ruth,six years old,suddenly recited a poem that no one of us had ever heard;it was perfect in sense,rhyme,rythmrhythm. We asked her where she got it and with some pumping learned that she had composed it herself.
While there I had a surprise.There was a picnic of the alumni and former students of Kingfisher College and I was guest of honor.It was amazing the way they shouted for the old days and for me.
Then a former students of Wayne,a fine young woman who teaches at Los Angeles,took me to see Hartley Alexander at Scripps College.

We went from Beverly Hill to SanFranciscoSan Francisco and visited a brother of Lucy and his family.He has had a hard life and now he and his wife run a boarding house,and,between gastronomic tasks, he reads Spinoza.

On our way from SanFranciscoSan Francisco we stopped a few minutes at Salt Lake and saw
A nephew of mine whom I had not seen
21
since our war to save the Phillipines Philippines.He is a fine chap.His wife,whom I had never before seen,was with him as were a son and a daughter and a brother-in-law of mine whom I last saw in 1896. He was husband of a sister who recently died.

In Denver we stopped with a brother and his wife,and then to Lincoln,which seems to me like a graveyard since Sam Avery died. While there I had two great thrills,one a visit frwith Dr.Lewis. But the maamazineg thing was to be receive a telephone call from Jim Brittain with the word that he was driving down to see me.He was with me for a half day and we had a magnificent time talking of Spengler and you. He averred that he owed his life to three men: Alexander,Neihardt and House. I was a bit stunned to mebe classed with the other two.
We are now staying in New York and Lucy is attending a class in writing articles for magazines and I work a bit when I get a chance
Now,this is a gossipy letter,and nothing else,but it may serve to get us into tougc once more.I need you.
Love to all,and an enormous lot to John,the ever fruitful poet from the Poet's Town.
Oh,I nearly forgot! The Nebraska folk had a gathering here at Columbia and I with others was called upon.I talked about you.
div1.note: Dr. Julius T. House, who was my dearest friend
